title: Two objects. Same room. Two different temperatures?

multiple-choice.question: What determines the rate at which heat is transferred from one object to another?

options.label: A
options.text: The temperature difference between the objects

options.label: B
options.text: The mass of the objects

options.label: C
options.text: The thermal conductivity of the objects

options.label: D
options.text: The shape and size of the objects

multiple-choice.question: Why did the ice cube melt more quickly on the aluminium block than on the plastic block?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the aluminium block was warmer than the plastic block

options.label: B
options.text: Because the aluminium block was a better conductor of heat

options.label: C
options.text: Because the plastic block was a better insulator of heat

options.label: D
options.text: Because the ice cube was in direct sunlight on the aluminium block

options.label: A
options.text: Because the hard drive was made of a denser material

options.label: B
options.text: Because the hard drive was larger than the book

options.label: C
options.text: Because the aluminium in the hard drive conducted heat away from the hand faster than the book

options.label: D
options.text: Because the hard drive was in a colder environment

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between feeling temperature and feeling the rate at which heat is conducted?

options.label: A
options.text: Feeling temperature is the same as feeling the rate at which heat is conducted

options.label: B
options.text: Feeling temperature is when you feel the actual temperature of an object, while feeling the rate at which heat is conducted is when you feel the rate at which heat is transferred to or from your hand

options.label: C
options.text: Feeling temperature is not directly perceivable, while feeling the rate at which heat is conducted is what we experience as temperature

options.label: D
options.text: Feeling temperature is only related to the environment, while feeling the rate at which heat is conducted is related to the object's material

multiple-choice.question: Why is it nicer to stand on a bath mat than on a towel after taking a shower in winter?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the bath mat is warmer than the towel

options.label: B
options.text: Because the bath mat is softer than the towel

options.label: C
options.text: Because the bath mat conducts heat less quickly away from your body than the towel

options.label: D
options.text: Because the bath mat is more absorbent than the towel

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the rate at which heat is transferred from one object to another?

options.label: A
options.text: Thermal conductivity

options.label: B
options.text: Heat transfer

options.label: C
options.text: Thermoconductivity

options.label: D
options.text: Convection

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the material of an object and its ability to conduct heat?

options.label: A
options.text: The material of an object determines its ability to conduct heat

options.label: B
options.text: The material of an object has no effect on its ability to conduct heat

options.label: C
options.text: The material of an object affects its ability to conduct heat, but only in certain situations

options.label: D
options.text: The material of an object only affects its color and texture

multiple-choice.question: If you touch two objects at the same temperature, but made of different materials, what might you experience?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The denser object will feel colder

options.label: C
options.text: The object with higher thermal conductivity will feel colder

options.label: D
options.text: The object with lower thermal conductivity will feel warmer

title: Can You Solve This?

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary objective of the experiment described in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: To test the participants' mathematical skills

options.label: B
options.text: To demonstrate the importance of teamwork in problem-solving

options.label: C
options.text: To generate a new sequence of numbers

options.label: D
options.text: To identify the underlying rule governing a sequence of numbers

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is a core principle of the scientific method?

options.label: A
options.text: To confirm existing theories through experimentation

options.label: B
options.text: To generate new theories through observation

options.label: C
options.text: To test hypotheses through trial and error

options.label: D
options.text: To attempt to disprove theories and uncover the truth

options.label: A
options.text: The concept of chaos theory

options.label: B
options.text: The theory of evolution

options.label: C
options.text: The white swan

options.label: D
options.text: The black swan

multiple-choice.question: What criticism does the speaker have regarding how people typically approach problems?

options.label: A
options.text: They lack strategic thinking and fail to propose sufficient solutions

options.label: B
options.text: They neglect to consider alternative perspectives and ignore conflicting evidence

options.label: C
options.text: They focus too much on finding a single correct answer

options.label: D
options.text: They attempt to confirm their pre-existing theories rather than disprove them

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the key to uncovering the truth?

options.label: A
options.text: Attempting to confirm pre-existing theories through experimentation

options.label: B
options.text: Ignoring conflicting evidence and focusing on affirmative answers

options.label: C
options.text: Generating new theories through observation and trial and error

options.label: D
options.text: Attempting to disprove pre-existing theories

multiple-choice.question: What pattern is the speaker attempting to identify in the sequence of numbers?

options.label: A
options.text: A pattern of decreasing numbers

options.label: B
options.text: A pattern of alternating numbers

options.label: C
options.text: A pattern of random numbers

options.label: D
options.text: A pattern of increasing numbers

multiple-choice.question: Why does the speaker emphasize the importance of attempting to disprove pre-existing theories?

options.label: A
options.text: To avoid conflicting evidence and confirm existing theories

options.label: B
options.text: To generate new theories and neglect alternative perspectives

options.label: C
options.text: To focus on affirmative answers and ignore negative results

options.label: D
options.text: To uncover the truth and avoid self-deception

multiple-choice.question: What inspired the speaker to create the experiment?

options.label: A
options.text: A personal experience with the scientific method

options.label: B
options.text: A conversation with someone about problem-solving

options.label: C
options.text: A book about chaos theory

options.label: D
options.text: The book "The Black Swan" by Nassim Taleb

multiple-choice.question: What is the central idea of the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The importance of confirming pre-existing theories through experimentation

options.label: B
options.text: The importance of ignoring conflicting evidence and focusing on affirmative answers

options.label: C
options.text: The importance of generating new theories through observation and trial and error

options.label: D
options.text: The importance of attempting to disprove pre-existing theories to uncover the truth

multiple-choice.question: What conclusion does the speaker draw about the scientific method?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a method to confirm existing theories through experimentation

options.label: B
options.text: It is a method to generate new theories through observation

options.label: C
options.text: It is a method to test hypotheses through trial and error

options.label: D
options.text: It involves attempting to disprove theories to uncover the truth

options.text: The dragon could secrete reactive "hypergolic" chemicals that react violently and shoot out of an orifice.

options.text: The dragon could have a special gland that produces fire.

options.label: D

options.label: C
options.text: To make the story richer and more immersive.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

title: What happens when you remove the hippocampus? - Sam Kean

options.label: A
options.text: To treat H.M.'s seizures by removing the hippocampus

options.label: B
options.text: To improve H.M.'s IQ through a partial lobotomy

options.label: C
options.text: To alleviate H.M.'s depression by modifying brain regions

options.text: To enhance H.M.'s memory by strengthening synaptic connections

multiple-choice.question: What was the immediate result of Dr. Scoville's surgery on H.M.?

options.label: B
options.text: H.M.'s seizures virtually disappeared, with no change in personality

options.label: C
options.text: H.M.'s memory improved, but his seizures persisted

options.label: D
options.text: H.M.'s IQ increased, but his seizures worsened

options.label: B
options.text: H.M.'s seizures worsened over time

options.label: C
options.text: H.M.'s memory was severely impaired, making it difficult to form new memories

options.label: D

options.text: H.M. had perfect short-term memory but struggled with long-term memory

options.label: B
options.text: H.M. had perfect long-term memory but struggled with short-term memory

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.text: Short-term memory uses the cortex, while long-term memory involves the hippocampus for consolidation

options.label: D

options.text: The transfer of memories from the cortex to the hippocampus for storage

options.label: B
options.text: The transfer of memories from the hippocampus to the cortex for permanent storage

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.text: Declarative memory is the memory of facts, while procedural memory is the memory of skills and habits

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: D

options.label: C

title: Should I stay or should I switch doors?

multiple-choice.question: In the 'Let's Make a Deal' game show, what is the initial probability of the car being behind the door chosen by the contestant?
What is the optimal strategy for the contestant to maximize their chances of winning the car?

options.label: A
options.text: Always stick with their initial choice

options.label: B
options.text: Always switch to the other unopened door

options.label: C
options.text: Randomly choose between sticking and switching

options.label: D
options.text: Don't switch until they see the other doors

multiple-choice.question: If the contestant switches, what is the probability of the car being behind the door they switch to?
In a version of the game with 100 doors, what is the probability of the car being behind the door the contestant initially chooses?
If Monty opens 98 of the 99 doors with zonks, what is the probability of the car being behind the remaining door?
How does Monty opening one of the two doors with zonks affect the probability of the car being behind the other unopened door?

options.label: A
options.text: The probability remains the same

options.label: B
options.text: The probability increases to 2/3

options.label: C
options.text: The probability decreases to 1/3

options.label: D
options.text: The probability becomes 1/2

multiple-choice.question: Why is it easier to see that switching is the best strategy in the game with 100 doors?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the numbers 1/100 and 99/100 are closer to each other

options.label: B
options.text: Because the numbers 1/3 and 2/3 are closer to each other

options.label: C
options.text: Because the probability of the car being behind the other doors is lower

options.label: D
options.text: Because the large difference between 1/100 and 99/100 makes the advantage of switching clearer

multiple-choice.question: What concept helps calculate the probability of the car being behind the door the contestant switches to?

options.label: A
options.text: Conditional probability

options.label: B
options.text: Independent probability

options.label: C
options.text: Mutual exclusivity

options.label: D
options.text: Bayes' theorem

multiple-choice.question: What is the probability of the car being behind the initially chosen door in the game with 100 doors?
If the contestant switches in the game with 100 doors, what is the probability of the car being behind the door they switch to?

title: The past, present and future of the bubonic plague - Sharon N. DeWitte

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of the world's population is estimated to have been destroyed by the Black Death?
According to DNA analysis of bone and tooth samples, what was the primary cause of the Black Death?

options.label: A
options.text: A mutation of the Yersinia pestis bacterium

options.label: B
options.text: A new strain of the Yersinia pestis bacterium

options.label: C
options.text: The same Yersinia pestis bacterium that causes bubonic plague today

options.label: D
options.text: A different bacterium

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between the medieval Black Death and modern instances of plague?

options.label: A
options.text: The Black Death was more widespread than modern instances

options.label: B
options.text: The Black Death had a higher mortality rate due to the lack of effective treatments

options.label: C
options.text: The Black Death was spread primarily through human-to-human contact, while modern instances are spread by rodent fleas

options.label: D
options.text: The Black Death was caused by a different bacterium

multiple-choice.question: According to genetic comparisons of ancient to modern strains of Yersinia pestis, what is the likely reason for the high mortality rate of the Black Death?

options.label: A
options.text: The parasite itself was more virulent

options.label: B
options.text: The environment was more conducive to the spread of the disease

options.label: C
options.text: The lack of effective treatments was the primary factor

options.label: D
options.text: The host population was more susceptible to infection due to poor health and malnutrition

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the rapid loss of population due to the Black Death, according to studies of London cemeteries?

options.label: A
options.text: A decrease in living standards

options.label: B
options.text: An increase in poverty and famine

options.label: C
options.text: A decrease in food availability

options.label: D
options.text: An increase in social mobility and living standards

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential benefit of research into the genetic consequences of the Black Death?

options.label: A
options.text: It may lead to the development of new treatments for the plague

options.label: B
options.text: It may help to understand how the plague spread

options.label: C
options.text: It may lead to the discovery of genes that confer immunities to multiple pathogens

options.label: D
options.text: It may lead to the development of a vaccine for the plague

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary factor that contributed to the destruction caused by the Black Death, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The virulence of the parasite

options.label: B
options.text: The environmental conditions, including climate change

options.label: C
options.text: The lack of effective treatments

options.label: D
options.text: The susceptibility of the host population due to poor health and malnutrition

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the high fertility rates and reduced harvest in Europe during the High Middle Ages?

options.label: A
options.text: An increase in living standards

options.label: B
options.text: A decrease in poverty

options.label: C
options.text: An increase in social mobility

options.label: D
options.text: A steady decline in living standards, marked by famine, poverty, and poor health

multiple-choice.question: What was the likely reason for the rapid spread of the Black Death, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The parasite itself was more virulent

options.label: B
options.text: The host population was more susceptible to infection

options.label: C
options.text: The disease was spread primarily through human-to-human contact

options.label: D
options.text: The lack of effective treatments and poor sanitation

multiple-choice.question: What is the current threat level of the bubonic plague, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: It has been eradicated

options.label: B
options.text: It is no longer a threat

options.label: C
options.text: It remains a significant threat for large-scale epidemics due to the emergence of drug-resistant strains

options.label: D
options.text: It continues to kill a few thousand people worldwide every year, but the threat of a large-scale epidemic has been largely eliminated

title: How optical illusions trick your brain - Nathan S. Jacobs

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of retinal ganglion cells in terms of visual information processing?

options.label: A
options.text: To detect color changes in the visual field

options.label: B
options.text: To detect movement and track objects

options.label: C
options.text: To transmit raw visual information to the brain without processing

options.label: D
options.text: To increase contrast through lateral inhibition

multiple-choice.question: Why does the brain's visual cortex operate on assumptions about lighting in images?

options.label: A
options.text: To enhance contrast and make edges more visible

options.label: B
options.text: To recognize objects and patterns quickly without considering lighting

options.label: C
options.text: Because it expects light to come from a single source, typically shining down from above

options.label: D
options.text: To create a 3D effect by adding texture and shading

multiple-choice.question: Which areas of the brain are primarily responsible for recognizing faces?

options.label: A
options.text: Fusiform face area only

options.label: B
options.text: Occipital lobe only

options.label: C
options.text: Temporal lobe only

options.label: D
options.text: Fusiform face area, occipital lobe, and temporal lobe

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why the brain uses lateral inhibition to increase contrast in visual information?

options.label: A
options.text: To detect movement and track objects

options.label: B
options.text: To create a 3D effect by adding depth cues

options.label: C
options.text: To enhance color perception and detect subtle changes

options.label: D
options.text: To make edges more visible and facilitate object recognition

multiple-choice.question: How does the brain allocate cognitive energy in terms of visual information processing?

options.label: A
options.text: By reducing cognitive load and processing less information

options.label: B
options.text: By processing all visual information equally without prioritization

options.label: C
options.text: By focusing on irrelevant details

options.label: D
options.text: By allocating cognitive energy efficiently and prioritizing important information

multiple-choice.question: Why does the brain's visual system use assumptions about visual information to create a tailored, edited vision of the world?

options.label: A
options.text: To reduce cognitive load and process less information

options.label: B
options.text: To create a 3D effect by adding random depth cues

options.label: C
options.text: To process all visual information without making assumptions

options.label: D
options.text: To allocate cognitive energy efficiently and prioritize important information

multiple-choice.question: Why does the brain's visual cortex create a 3D concave or convex shape based on shading patterns in images?

options.label: A
options.text: To enhance contrast and make edges more visible

options.label: B
options.text: To create a 3D effect by adding random shading patterns

options.label: C
options.text: Because it expects light to come from a single source, typically shining down from above

options.label: D
options.text: To recognize objects and patterns quickly without considering shading patterns

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the brain's visual cortex in interpreting shading patterns in images?

options.label: A
options.text: To ignore shading patterns and focus on color

options.label: B
options.text: To use shading patterns to detect movement

options.label: C
options.text: To assume light comes from multiple sources

options.label: D
options.text: To use shading patterns to infer 3D shapes and depth

multiple-choice.question: How does the brain's visual system prioritize information when processing visual stimuli?

options.label: A
options.text: By focusing on irrelevant details

options.label: B
options.text: By processing all visual information equally without prioritization

options.label: C
options.text: By prioritizing color over shape and texture

options.label: D
options.text: By prioritizing edges, shapes, and patterns relevant to object recognition

multiple-choice.question: What is the brain's role in terms of cognitive energy allocation and construction of a world on the fly?

options.label: A
options.text: To reduce cognitive load and process less information

options.label: B
options.text: To process all visual information without prioritization or construction

options.label: C
options.text: To create a 3D effect by adding depth cues

options.label: D
options.text: To allocate cognitive energy efficiently, prioritize important information, and construct a world on the fly

title: The secret lives of baby fish - Amy McDermott

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the fish species shown in the transcript as a baby and an adult?

options.label: A
options.text: Yellow Tang Surgeonfish

options.label: B
options.text: Clownfish

options.label: C
options.text: Angelfish

options.label: D
options.text: Butterflyfish

multiple-choice.question: Approximately what percentage of the Earth's surface is made up of coral reefs, which are home to over a quarter of known fish species?
What event marks the beginning of the life cycle of most coral reef fish?

options.label: A
options.text: When they hatch from eggs on the coral reef.

options.label: B
options.text: When their parents release sperm and eggs into the water column.

options.label: C
options.text: When they are already adults.

options.label: D
options.text: When they settle on a coral reef.

multiple-choice.question: What is a unique characteristic of the larvae of many coral reef fish species?

options.label: A
options.text: They have fully developed gills from birth.

options.label: B
options.text: They are unexpectedly strong swimmers and can move vertically in the water column.

options.label: C
options.text: They are slow swimmers and rely on ocean currents.

options.label: D
options.text: They are only able to swim horizontally.

multiple-choice.question: How do larvae navigate to their eventual homes on coral reefs?

options.label: A
options.text: Via a complex suite of sensory systems, detecting both sound and smell.

options.label: B
options.text: By following the currents with no control over their movement.

options.label: C
options.text: By using their sense of touch to detect reef structures.

options.label: D
options.text: By swimming randomly until they find a suitable reef.

multiple-choice.question: What is a unique behavior exhibited by some larvae when searching for their adult habitats?

options.label: A
options.text: They only head for far-flung locales miles away from their birth place.

options.label: B
options.text: They use smell and other sensory cues to navigate back to the reefs where they were born.

options.label: C
options.text: They remain in the same location where they were born and settle on the nearest reef.

options.label: D
options.text: They do not use any sensory cues and rely on chance.

multiple-choice.question: What is the observed behavior of larvae when they find a suitable coral reef?

options.label: A
options.text: They risk it all in one jump from the water column, hoping to land in exactly the right spot to settle down and metamorphose into adults.

options.label: B
options.text: They drop down in the water column to check out the reef below and can jump back up if conditions aren't right.

options.label: C
options.text: They swim away to find another reef that might be more suitable.

options.label: D
options.text: They remain in the water column and wait for the right moment to settle.

multiple-choice.question: What are some challenges in studying the geographic movements of individual larvae?

options.label: A
options.text: It is difficult to track them due to their small size and the vast ocean environment.

options.label: B
options.text: It is difficult to study their behavior in the wild without interfering with their natural movements.

options.label: C
options.text: We don't know the exact environmental cues and behaviors they use to navigate to the reefs they will call home.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What was once believed to be true about the larvae of coral reef fish?

options.label: A
options.text: They are strong swimmers and can move vertically in the water column.

options.label: B
options.text: They are passive drifters with no control over their movement.

options.label: C
options.text: They have fully developed gills from birth and are well-equipped to navigate the ocean.

options.label: D
options.text: They are able to navigate back to their birthplace using magnetic fields.

multiple-choice.question: What remains largely mysterious about the lives of baby fish?

options.label: A
options.text: Their adult habitats and feeding behaviors.

options.label: B
options.text: Their behavior in the wild and social interactions.

options.label: C
options.text: Their development from larvae to adults.

options.label: D
options.text: Their geographic movements and the exact environmental cues and behaviors they use to navigate to their adult habitats.
